@2:39 We discuss the planting of trees . The problem we have is related to trees but it isn't the trees. The problem is our disturbance of the soil in particular the soil ecology . In a sense the soil is another world much like the world above ground. When we pull trees out of the ground or chop them down we essentially drastically alter the micro climate established in that area. The change affects the biology in the soil like fungai ,bacteria species and biology that all co depend on each other. When these links between species reduces or collapses the ability for trees to feed collapses too. In this way for us to plant a trre into poor soil ( limited biodiversity /biology under ground ) is like dropping off a human in a desert like environment and expect them to survive. In my opinion this is a very ineffcient way to bring back an area from it's forested past. Add to this not only is the soil affected badly but the climate in that area , the balance between water evaporation to atmosphere and the water table below. The destruction of soils means that water cannot be retained by the soil but rather runs off into the streams and with it dragging any human compounds with it fertilizers, pesticides. Now we affect water ways and kill of the ecosystems in those regions. The effect of tree /forest cutting is so damaging that it is capable of collapsing regions completely or down to such a small scale of life that we stop absorbing quality nutrients because crops are so poor in natural nutrient. The mono culture in farming reduces the soil biology drastically and biodiversity and the regions begin to slowly decay of all wild life above and below ground. This is evident with bee population collapses but this is happening in many levels of animal and microbiology. The take away is to plant trees is extremely inefficient and costly , many trees may simply not be able to grow without intervention. What we need to plant or do is create soils environments that breed micro biology to build soil and this usually happens in an order from low grasses ,fungai to larger plants and trees. Biodoverse soil allows for plant density ( just like our old forests) Not only can they self sustain extremely dense forest but the size of trees also becomes possible. Large trees 100's of years old of which many are now chopped down provide extremely deep biodiversity .Think of them as the natural sky scrapers reaching high into the sky but also very deep into the earth. That depth provides robustness to the under life of the soil. Without the microbiological life in soil there are no plants ,no trees no humans. Create compost, and plant that everywhere and let the trees come naturally. Forests are the batteries of our source of air they provide us with stability and robusteness in climate and air for us to breathe.

-There are ~3 trillion trees in the world. Yes, 3,000,000,000,000 or 150,000×20,000,000

-Trees germinate nauturally, producing millions of seeds throughout their individual life spans.
-Proper forest management - rather than hands off conservation - dramatically increases the economic and environmental value of existing forestland, as well as practically eliminates the threat of destructive and avoidable forest fires.

All Eucalyptus or gumtrees here in Australia can not only survive fire, they actively promote fire. They evaporate out their eucalyptus oil (yes!) on hot days (hence the Blue Mountains outside Sydney are called that, as the oil in the air turn into a blue haze from all the evaporated oil), hoping that a fire will start due to a lighting strike. The oil will help the fire to spread and become more intense. The fire will burn all trees with bark on their stem, but gumtrees drop their bark, so they can survive the fire. The gum-nuts also only germinate after a fire, so their offspring takes over burnt areas from other species after those have been killed by the fire.

In practice, every single forest in the world needs fire every now and then. In regular uncontrolled forest fires that appear often enough, fire will destroy only the undergrowth while large trees remain alive.

Humans are unfortunately taking the fires down before they can do their job. Because of that, for many decades the undergrowth is spreading wild as well as a plenty of flammable material is accumulating at the forest floor. Once these many decades of stored material catch fire, it burns hot enough and long enough to destroy even the strongest and oldest of trees.

The best example of this mechanism are now fires in Siberia. Absolutely destructive unstoppable walls of fire that jump across roads and rivers like nothing. It is a strange sight to behold, when you see that all of your hard work in an attempt to help nature, have completely turned around and is trying to kill you.

There’s an important point to be made here.

We’ve come to associate wildfires with disaster, but as Destin just showed they’re natural occurrences, and these trees have evolved to survive through them. When people started living closer and closer to forests, we started preventing wildfires from occurring in order to protect the people. This, however, became a problem, since more and more dead, combustible matter starts accumulating on the ground. This causes wildfires, when they do occur, to burn way more violently than they would’ve if we hadn’t intervened and stopped them from occurring in the first place. The massive wildfires we’ve seen in recent years are, to some degree, directly related to this. Just goes to show that what we think is best for the environment is not always the case.

OK, Destin...I'm watching a lot of tree videos in My Subscriptions, but I need to put in my $.02 as the eldest child on a reforestry tree farm (12,000 planted);

$20,000,000 to Arbor Day Foundation for 20,000,000 trees "planted" is a nice thing to say and makes people feel good who can only give $$, but what is the 5 or 10-year survival rate for those saplings? And I know what a $1 tree is, its a 1-year old sapling, that's what the 1st 3,000 of our trees were.

THEY DON'T LIVE unless you are planting in your yard where you see it every day, baby it, water it in the summer, and keep the critters from eating it. I'd make a generous estimate we had...10% survival on those trees. We moved to a mix of 1-2 year old saplings for the next 6,000 and it got better, but still sucked. The final 3,000 or so were ALL 2+ year old saplings; might have gotten to 25% survival on those.

The last 12 I planted were 3-5 year old trees, a different and unique breed, so only a few were purchased, but they were weed-barriered, caged, mulched, and given vitamins in their water for the 1st 3 summer months: 100% survival so far (2 years), even through the Polar Vortex winter (we had a week of -60 to -50 F temps in WI). These are not "yard decoration" trees, they are full out in the field, 1/4 mile from nearest building. ZERO babying after initial start conditions.

I've watched several videos on this project and it's near and all, but I have a lot of concerns with this
1. Are they actually planting "trees" and jump-starting reforestation, or are they dropping tree pucks from the air?
2. Those shrubs are carbon sinks as well, and they'll grow without any intervention or fundraising needed.
3. Those shrubs pave the way for the "trees" to come later. While trees can be planted to speed up the "forest", it will happen by itself as well (except, perhaps due to warmer climates, see below)
4. If we're raising $20mil to replant the same kinds of trees that won't regrow due to the climate, are we wasting the money being used to plant them?
5. While I love fundraising and charity, charitable organizations are prone to corruption and misuse like any human organization, especially when very large amounts get involved. Who is overseeing this fundraiser and actually holding the Arbor Day people accountable, or, who is counting the trees being planted and the use of the funds? The mention of longleaf pines brought back some old memories.

We had a bunch around Fort Polk when I was serving there in 1982-1983. They didn't look quite like the ones that you pictured because they were growing out in the open rather than in a forest. Somewhere, I have some old 35mm pictures of them, some with the sunset as background. There were boots hanging off of the long horizontal branches because of the old tradition of hanging up your boots when you are about to leave the service.

The ecosystem you were showing looked very familiar. I did a certain amount of wandering around, but got more familiar with the area during military exercises.

Around here (Michigan,) the dominant conifers are red pines (we have about six or seven acres of them on our ten acre parcel) and white pines. The deciduous trees are a lot more diverse. Alas, we are losing some. The Emerald Ash Borer is doing bad things to our ash trees. We have a bunch of elm trees at the front of our property that are struggling. They are successfully reseeding themselves, but they don't last long. Happily, we have an isolated elm just outside the window here that seems to be doing well. There is also an isolated chestnut tree that took a hard hit, but is still alive.

Lots of different types of pine trees need fire to thrive.  Some have evolved to grow extra thick, sponge-like bark to soak up rain during the storm that will insulate them from fires started by lightening strikes.  The fire burns away the underbrush and also burns the small branches and suckers growing on the trees, just as if a person had come along and pruned them.  Some of them have developed so that their pine cones won't open and drop the seeds until they are exposed to an unnaturally high temperature only reached when a fire has burned the area, ensuring the seeds will drop on soil free of underbrush so the young tree won't have to compete for light.  Nature is a wonderful thing.

One thing to note, planting too much of just Pine can be very harmful. It can become a monoculture and get pests easier, and fall over during strong winds or storms, especially ice storms that freeze the needles and make trees much more heavier. Pine or spruce forests are the ones that get destroyed the most, and it can be prevented by just planting some leafy trees every now and then. Leafy varieties are sturdier and can protect the pines from the winds, and just for growth and health purposes, mixed plantings of forests are key.
One other good thing is to not just plant in perfect rows, but experiment with different shapes, like nature does.

You do realize that trees are completely carbon neutral don't you?  Yes, living trees pull carbon out of the air the whole time that they are alive, but once they die, dead trees are rapidly decomposed by the soil microbiota.   During the process of decomposition all of the carbon that was (temporarily) stored in the trees gets released right back into the atmosphere.  Therefore, I'm sorry to say that planting more trees will literally do nothing to combat climate change.  Best to devote your time, effort, and money to something else that might actually be beneficial to the cause you are espousing, rather than waste it on a meaningless gesture like this proposal.

Eucalyptus trees also need fire! They actually need fire to germinate, like a lot of Australian tree species. Eucalypts and Australian acacia trees have a thermal-activated endosperm layer that won't allow the seeds to germinate until they hit at least about 100C. At that point, they know (well, "know") that there's no other competition around, so they'll start booking it for the canopy as fast as possible before the underbrush grows back. Eucalyptus trees actually EXPLODE when heated, which is how they disperse their seeds! During a bushfire, eucalyptus trees at the right stage of life will explode, potentially killing the parent tree but scattering its seeds for hundreds of metres around. Some animals also disperse their seeds without fires, but they won't germinate until they get burnt out.

Hey Destin, over here in Germany in the small ,ountain range where I spent 10 years of my life called Harz - and probably not just there but all over Europe - I just recently got wind of the massive forest decline that's happening there.
In short, up until the mid 19th century all the way through the medieval and renaissance period, the people living here used to cut down enormous amounts of wood. There are numerous cities literally called "cleared woodland X" like Wernigerode, Harzgerode, Osterode, Elbingerode... the list goes on. But, during the 19th century people started to take notice and in order to cope with the rising shortage of wood they planted most of the current population but mainly with spruce monocultures. So now with climate change and an increasingly endangering bark beetle plague it's in a serious condition.


So watch out when you plant trees, that it's not just one kind and that it can withstand not just current conditions, but those 20-50 years from now.

I have my BS in wildlife sciences. The reality is that most trees do wonderful in a nice sandy loam soil. But in nature isn't not about what they do best in, its about what they can tolerate compared to the competition. Bald Cyprus for instance love well drained sandy loam soil (so long as they are frequently watered) but they can tolerate the total immersion of their roots in water. Few trees can do that but far more trees can out compete Cyprus in the sandy loam so the Cyprus is relegated to where it can tolerate. Silvics can tell us some very important particulars but generally, well drained, frequently watered, sandy loam soils will grow anything as long as the temps and daylight times are right.
